sect1.title: Overview
sect1.para: The proxies created for a singleton session bean interact with client side invocation handlers. The responsibility of these client side invocation handlers is to (somehow) pass on the control to the container which might reside on a remote server. The invocation handler uses the new SPI RemotingContainer and just invokes the invoke() method on the RemotingContainer. Implementations of the RemotingContainer will have the necessary knowledge to (somehow) pass on the control to the container on the remote server. In this chapter, we will look at one such implementation of RemotingContainer.

sect1.title: JBoss Remoting 2.x based implementation of RemotingContainer
sect1.para:
A JBoss Remoting 2.x based implementation of the RemotingContainer is available here. Internally it uses the default InvokerLocator URL (or the one overridden in metadata) to connect to the JBRemoting server. The important thing to notice here is that it expects a "SIMPLE" subsystem to be available on this Remoting connector (unlike the older client side interceptors which expect an "AOP" subsystem). The JBossRemotingContainer creates a InvocationRequest which contains the container id as well as a RemotableContainerInvocation.
Client side interceptors need to be invoked in the JBossRemotingContainer before passing on the control to the JBRemoting server side invocation handler. This is currently a TODO

The "SIMPLE" subsystem is backed by a RemotingInvocationHandler which is a server side JBRemoting invocation handler (and hence implements org.jboss.remoting.ServerInvocationHandler). The goal of this RemotingInvocationHandler is to remote any AOP aspects from the client to remote container interaction. Internally, when a call reaches the RemotingInvocationHandler, it obtains a container id (TODO: we need to discuss this) from the InvocationRequest. The container id is populated in the InvocationRequest by the client side JBossRemotingContainer. An container registry exists on the server side with all registered container ids. The RemotingInvocationHandler then looks up this registry to get hold of the (new SPI based) EJBContainer and invokes EJBContainer.invoke(ContainerInvocation) method.
With this new "SIMPLE" subsystem, the dynamicInvoke method (of the old jboss-ejb3-core container) is not used. And all AOP semantics are skipped
Here's the server configuration (notice the "SIMPLE" subsystem) from the ejb3-connectors-jboss-beans.xml:
<!-- Remoting Server Configuration --> <bean name="ServerConfiguration" class="org.jboss.remoting.ServerConfiguration"> <property name="invocationHandlers"> <map keyClass="java.lang.String" valueClass="java.lang.String"> <entry> <key>AOP</key> <value> org.jboss.aspects.remoting.AOPRemotingInvocationHandler </value> </entry> <entry> <key>SIMPLE</key> <value> org.jboss.ejb3.singleton.impl.remoting.RemotingInvocationHandler </value> </entry> </map> </property> </bean>
